awd_titl_txt: Rheology of Multi-Phase Mantle Rocks to 800 km Depth
awd_abstract_narration:
A quantitative description of the plastic properties of mantle rocks at mantle conditions has long been the pursuit of geoscientists, as these properties control the motion of plates, define the nature of earthquakes, and constrain the evolution of the Earth.  Over the last decade, a series of experimental technique breakthroughs have enabled the team to deform rock samples with controlled flow rates and at the pressure and temperature relevant to the Earth’s interior.   However, even with increased knowledge on the rheological properties of minerals such as olivine, pyroxene, garnet, periclase, perovskite, etc., the flow law for a real rock sample is still unknown.   An establishment of flow laws for composite rock requires not only the properties of its constituents, but also the understanding of interactions among them.   Synchrotron X-ray radiation coupled with multi-anvil high pressure deformation apparatus, the current state of the art technique for rheological experiments, is the team's tool to probe these interactions inside the rock under mantle conditions.   In this project, the goal is to (1) define the flow law of the rocks at conditions spanning the region from the upper mantle through the top of the lower mantle using peridotite as the sample. (2) Pursue specific mixing scenarios that will give added insights into the rheological properties of regions actively undergoing phase transitions and to better understand regions, such as the lower mantle, where there is a mixture of a very strong phase and a very weak phase. This project will support the training of a graduate student, and develop and extend novel experimental tools on national X-ray synchrotron beamline facilities that are open to the scientific community.

The theme of this project is to provide an experimentally based reference for the viscosity of the mantle as a function of depth to 800 km. The data will naturally include the effect of mineralogical and compositional changes with depth due to pressure-induced phase transitions. By measuring rheological flow laws of a model mantle rock, the investigators expect to see the total effect of depth on the rheological properties. By comparing the rock data with olivine data, one can identify the contribution of the multi-phase aggregate properties to the effective flow law. The effect of mixing will be addressed not only with the mechanical deformation data but also on a microstructure level with post-experiment study of the final sample. This study will use multi-anvil high pressure deformation equipment at synchrotron facilities that have already provided deformation conditions to pressures equivalent to 600 km depth. This project will further develop the capabilities to achieve 800 km conditions for the highest-pressure measurements. The synchrotron X-ray provides stress and strain data in situ allowing documentation of sample evolution during deformation. In addition, stress is determined from the analysis of each diffraction peak yielding information about the stress partitioning between the minerals, and for each mineral, between sub-populations of grains that share a common crystallographic orientation relative to the stress field. All of this information constrains the deformation process in each mineral and the relative strengths of each mineral. This project will develop techniques suitable for synchrotron high-pressure research. The proposed research has potential to open new frontiers by combining different techniques and applying them to high pressure in situ studies. In particular, the experimental protocol that enables these experiments to 400 km depth is currently developed. This research program will refine the experimental tools to enable the experiments to pressures equivalent to 800 km depth. This will expand the national research base for high pressure deformation studies. The techniques that evolve from this project will be open to all users of the beamline through a proposal system to all scientists interested in carrying out these high-pressure experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes of the grant: Rheology of Multi-Phase Mantle Rocks to 800 km Depth

 

            The materials of the Earth are in constant motion as evidenced by plate tectonics, earthquakes, volcanic eruptions and the like.  This motion is induced by combinations of thermal, gravitational, or chemical forces.  At the material, these forces are manifest as stress that push and deform the materials.  Driven by the desire to model these deformations, we strive to measure and understand the flow strength of rocks at the pressure, temperature, stress, and chemical makeup of the material as a function of depth.  This is a rather complex issue.  Each rock is composed of several minerals.  These minerals change with pressure and temperature.  The strength properties of the individual minerals are still poorly defined over the range of conditions that exist in the Earth.  The strength of the composite is not necessarily well-defined by the strength of the constituent minerals.  For example, the strength of a composite of a very strong and a very weak material may be controlled by the weak material even at small levels of concentration.  Plus, interactions between mineral types can create overall strengthening or weakening relative to the individual phases. 

            The major scientific outcome of this grant is an experimental constraint on the flow strength of one high pressure mineral (davemaoite) that has not been previously measured at conditions of constant pressure, temperature, and strain rate.  This mineral is expected to be the third most abundant mineral in the Earth.  It has the composition of CaSiO3 and in the perovskite structure.  Davemaoite is a high-pressure phase (P>14GPa) that cannot be recovered to room pressure and temperature as it reverts to a glass as pressure is removed.  Thus, it must be made and characterized in the same experiment and flow properties cannot be measured at low pressure.  A recent paper by Imoor et.al. (Nature, 2022) reported that the flow strength of davemaoite was very low and thereby would drastically lower the strength of the mantle in some regions compared to previous thought.  They used a diamond anvil cell and synthesized the sample after pressurization and heating.  The experimental tools restrict them from confirming that the sample is in fact deforming.  Because of the importance of the impact of their result, we turned our focus to measure the strength of this material in our new high-pressure system.  We found that the strength of davemaoite was not low and that it approaches the previously reported strength of bridgmanite, the dominant mineral in the lower mantle and also with the perovskite crystal structure.  We conclude that their sample was not at a stress that would cause plastic deformation and that the stress had probably been released by the phase transformation that formed davemaoite. 

            A second major outcome of this grant is the development of the infrastructure to conduct these experiments.  Specifically, we used a 1000 ton press with a DT25 environmental stage.  Prior to this study, we developed and have used a DDIA high-pressure system to generate pressure and temperature with the ability to superimpose a uniaxial stress on the sample that is sufficient to make the sample plastically flow.  With the synchrotron, we can measure stress and strain rate as the sample is held at constant P, T.  Our flow strength measurements occur by measuring stress when the strain rate and stress have reached a steady-state condition.  The system can create pressure to 12 GPa and temperature to 1700K (corresponding to about 400 km depth in the Earth).  We subsequently developed the DT25 system that should be capable of sustaining 30 GPa and 2000K.  These are the first published data using the new system.  To reach this point we needed to develop the cell assembly that can work at these conditions, and we needed to create and adopt software to analyze the monochromatic x-ray data that we have at the synchrotron (previously we used white radiation).  These tasks have now been completed and the system is online at the XPD beamline at the NSLS II synchrotron.  Access is granted through the NSLS II general user program to all scientist through a NSLS II proposal review system.  To our knowledge, there is one other DT25 in operation in the world and is located in Japan.

These new tools project a new future where the data on flow strength at a defined strain rate will be obtained.  Yet, we still need data on aggregates of minerals ie rocks in order to firm up our idea of how different regions will flow.  Furthermore, we need more insights into moving to much slower strain rates, the one important parameter that laboratory studies cannot match the environment of the Earth interior.
